Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The subject area of the project for this fellowship to Ben Krause is harmonic analysis. The host institution for the fellowship is the University of British Columbia, and the sponsoring scientist is Izabella Laba.

This award was supported with funding from the Office of International Science & Engineering

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of the project was advancing the field of pointwise ergodic theory, through the investigation of harmonic-analytic phenomenon on the integers. The aim of the project was ultimately to prove pointwise ergodic theorems for non-conventional bilinear polynomial averages, a famous open problem that has resisted considerable efforts, notably those of Jean Bourgain. The first effort in this direction was establishing the pointwise convergence of a maximally modulated ergodic singular integral, whose behavior formed a "toy model" for the bilinear problem, with additional technical difficulties. The two papers produced from this work, joint with Joris Roos, have been accepted pending review to the Journal of the EMS. The second work in this direction, joint with Mariusz Mirek and Terence Tao, resolved the case of pointwise convergence of bilinear polynomial averages in the case where the first polynomial action on the first function is linear. It represents the first part of a program to establish a pointwise convergence analogue to Walsh's ergodic theorem, and an approach was developed to handle higher degrees of multi-linearity.

During the course of the award duration, the PI offered several graduate topics courses in discrete harmonic analysis, and began collaborations with six junior postdocs, including three women, all of which lead to accepted papers, in journals such as IMRN. The PI also has produced an introductory manuscript to the field, which he has disseminated to several universities, and is in contact with the AMS about publication details.
